prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We have picked the resolution elements so that, in that we can achieve ~50 elements over the expected line width while also minimizing the data rate. This is chosen that that if the CO lines are brighter than our low estimate here, we can image the lines using smaller channel widths than our requested 50 km/s. Additionally, the expected source integrated line flux is high enough that we expect to can spectrally resolve the line using channel widths smaller than our requested 50 km/s.

For all sources except for MIPSJ1428 we request 0.5 imaging of each line. Given the expected source sizes of 1 - 1.4 (Stacey et al. 2010, Brisbin et al. 2015) this is sufficient to compare the spatial extent of the CO emission of each source and transition, while also minimize our requested integration time. For MIPSJ1428, owing to its brightness and smaller source size we request a smaller resolution of 0.3 for the (3-2), (5-4) and (6-5) observations, while for the (2-1) observations we request 0.5 to avoid baselines longer than 2km. Given our expected source sizes we expect no issues with resolving out of flux.

For all sources except MIPSJ1428 to determine our sensitivity we have taken the observed CO(2-1) or (3-2) line fluxes from CO-I S. Hailey-Dunsheath obtained on the IRAM 30 meter (see Table 1) and scaled them to an expected line flux of the other transitions using the model CO SLED for a high-z star-forming disk from Bournaud et al. 2014. This CO SLED, based on the work of Daddi et al. 2015 is the minimu CO excitation, and hence CO line fluxes, we would expect from our sources. To estimate a flux density at the line peak we assume a line width of 250 km/s, an ALMA beam of 0.5 and the source sizes from Stacey et al. 2010 and Brisbin et al. 2015 listed in Table 1. For our requested 1 sensitivity we use a 50 km/s line width and require at least a ~3 detection of the line peak. This will allow for sufficient measurement of the spatial scale of the CO emission, while extracting the line over the entire source will provide a measure of the line flux for our SLED analysis. We list our requested line sensitivities for each transition in Table 1. While we configure ALMA to provide a large continuum bandwidth we expect to detect the continuum of our sources in only a few cases, and only at the highest-J transitions. Continuum detection is not a requirement of our program, but when it is detect can be used to improve our constraints on our sources FIR luminosity. We have selected a channel width above 50 km/s, so that we can have at least 3 channels across our estimated linewidth, while keeping the requested total integration time to observe all of the lines for any single source to less than 2.5 hours. We determined our required sensitivity similarly for MIPSJ1428, except that given its brightness, we use 10 km/s for the CO(2-1) observations and a smaller beam (0.3) along with 50 km/s channels for observations of the (3-2), (5-4) and (6-5).

We have picked the resolution elements so that, in that we can achieve ~50 elements over the expected line width while also minimizing the data rate. This is chosen that that if the CO lines are brighter than our low estimate here, we can image the lines using smaller channel widths than our requested 50 km/s. Additionally, the expected source integrated line flux is high enough that we expect to can spectrally resolve the line using channel widths smaller than our requested 50 km/s.

For all sources except for MIPSJ1428 we request 0.5? imaging of each line. Given the expected source sizes of 1 - 1.4? (Stacey et al. 2010, Brisbin et al. 2015) this is sufficient to compare the spatial extent of the CO emission of each source and transition, while also minimize our requested integration time. For MIPSJ1428, owing to its brightness and smaller source size we request a smaller resolution of 0.3? for the (3-2), (5-4) and (6-5) observations, while for the (2-1) observations we request 0.5? to avoid baselines longer than 2km. Given our expected source sizes we expect no issues with resolving out of flux.

Additionally, the expected source integrated line flux is high enough that we expect to can spectrally resolve the line using channel widths smaller than our requested 50 km/s.

For all sources except for MIPSJ1428 we request 0.5? imaging of each line. Given the expected source sizes of 1 - 1.4? (Stacey et al. 2010, Brisbin et al. 2015) this is sufficient to compare the spatial extent of the CO emission of each source and transition, while also minimize our requested integration time. For MIPSJ1428, owing to its brightness and smaller source size we request a smaller resolution of 0.3? for the (3-2), (5-4) and (6-5) observations, while for the (2-1) observations we request 0.5? to avoid baselines longer than 2km. Given our expected source sizes we expect no issues with resolving out of flux.

For all sources except MIPSJ1428 to determine our sensitivity we have taken the observed CO(2-1) or (3-2) line fluxes from CO-I S. Hailey-Dunsheath obtained on the IRAM 30 meter (see Table 1) and scaled them to an expected line flux of the other transitions using the model CO SLED for a high-z star-forming disk from Bournaud et al. 2014. This CO SLED, based on the work of Daddi et al. 2015 is the minimu CO excitation, and hence CO line fluxes, we would expect from our sources. To estimate a flux density at the line peak we assume a line width of 250 km/s, an ALMA beam of 0.5 and the source sizes from Stacey et al. 2010 and Brisbin et al. 2015 listed in Table 1. For our requested 1 sensitivity we use a 50 km/s line width and require at least a ~3 detection of the line peak. This will allow for sufficient measurement of the spatial scale of the CO emission, while extracting the line over the entire source will provide a measure of the line flux for our SLED analysis. We list our requested line sensitivities for each transition in Table 1. While we configure ALMA to provide a large continuum bandwidth we expect to detect the continuum of our sources in only a few cases, and only at the highest-J transitions. Continuum detection is not a requirement of our program, but when it is detect can be used to improve our constraints on our sources FIR luminosity. We have selected a channel width above 50 km/s, so that we can have at least 3 channels across our estimated linewidth, while keeping the requested total integration time to observe all of the lines for any single source to less than 2.5 hours. We determined our required sensitivity similarly for MIPSJ1428, except that given its brightness, we use 10 km/s for the CO(2-1) observations and a smaller beam (0.3) along with 50 km/s channels for observations of the (3-2), (5-4) and (6-5).

We have picked the resolution elements so that, in that we can achieve ~50 elements over the expected line width while also minimizing the data rate. Hailey-Dunsheath obtained on the IRAM 30 meter (see Table 1) and scaled them to an expected line flux of the other transitions using the model CO SLED for a high-z star-forming disk from Bournaud et al. 2014. This will allow for sufficient measurement of the spatial scale of the CO emission, while extracting the line over the entire source will provide a measure of the line flux for our SLED analysis. prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose ALMA Cycle-3 observations to spatially resolve the CO(2-1), (3-2), (5-4) and (6-5) lines in four star-forming galaxies at z~1-2. These observations will let us determine the spatial extent of the molecular gas, the level of CO excitation and the importance of non-PDR modes of [CII] emissionX-ray dominated regions, shocks, ionized gas, and low-metallicity environmentsin star-forming [CII] emitters at high-z. Using our spectrometers ZEUS-1&2 we have been pioneers in the use of the [CII] line at high-z and found early galaxies exhibit [CII] to FIR luminosity ratios spanning a wide range from ~10^-4 to 10^-2. Our proposed observations will also let us test our model that suggests sources with high [CII]/FIR ratios have extended, kilo-parsec scale star-formation while low-ratios indicate compact star-formation possibly powered by mergers. Ultimately our proposed observations will provide key insights into [CII] emission, which given the importance of the [CII] line in the ALMA era, will be crucial for correctly interpreting the results of future studies
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Nucleo de Astronomia, Universidad Diego Portales
Center for Radiophysics and Space Research, Cornell University
Submillimeter Astrophysics Group, California Institute of Technology
